div1.p: Matas provides references on yellow fever, and gives information on his own work and experience with the disease.

div1.head: Letter from Rudolph Matas to Howard A. Kelly, April 14, 1905

opener.dateline:
DR. RUDOLPH MATAS.
2256 ST. CHARLES AVE.
TELEPHONE 137.
New Orleans, April 14th.1905 190___

div1.p:
While I am looking up some more references to personal
letters and other information which may give you the “vivid”
material need for your paper, I would suggest that you look up the
following references: “1. The diary of a Samaritan by a member of the
Howard Association New Orleans, 1878, Published by Harper Bros.
2) Yellow Fever, Heroes, Honors and Horrors of 1878 by J.P. Dromgoole,
Louisville, Ky. 1879. You might find some suggestive paragraphs in
“Chita” A memory of the last island by Lafcadio Hearn, Harper Bros.
New York, 1900, in which you will find something that may interest you
on P.162 et seq. This is one of Hearn's most extrordinary books and
I am sure you will enjoy reading it any how, for the intense vividness
of its portrayal of our Gulf coast and the marsh girt country of the
great Delta.

You can, I am sure, find a great many sources of inspiration by
looking into the general references on yellow fever epidermiology, etc.,
from the from the professional point of view in the Surgeon General's
Library; and, on yellow fever bibliography from the laymen's or popular
point of view, in the Congressional Library. The majority of the re-
ferences that we have in our Howard Library and Fisk Library can be
obtained in Washington.

I also enclose a reprint of a paper read at our Parish Society in 1897
It simply shows how our eyes were shut to the tryuth even at so late a
date as 1897. I remember when I was writing this paper (it was a very
hurried affair I assure you) that I thought of embodying a discussion
on Finlay's earlier researches on the Mosquito as the agent of trans-
mission, which I was the first to translate into English (New Orleans
Med'l. & Surg'l. Jn'l.) in 1881 .But in 1897 we were so engrossed with

New Orleans,_______________190___
Sanarelli and his fascinating paper that we forgot almost evrything
else. Of course, the mode of transmission by fomites and atmospheric
contamination, referred to so graphically and vividly by Dr. Shannon
in his letter to Dr. Bemiss, and which we still believed in in 1897,
is curious and not easily explained in the light of past evidence. I
have no doubt, however, that the case of Dr. Shannon would have been
easily accounted for if the attention of the observers at that time,
had been directed to the possibilities of mosquito innoculation. I
am now very sorry indeed that my interest in Sanarelli's work in 1897
and the brief time at my disposal made me oblivious of Finleay's great
and fundamental work on the mosquito transmission of yellow fever
previously referred to. Before closing, I must correct the impression
conveyed in your letter that I had any experience in Memphis in 1878
I have never visited Memphis except as a transient traveller, en
route to some other place. My first professional experience with
yellow fever in 1878 when I was still an interne in the Charity Hospi-
tal where I contracted my second attack of the disease. I again saw
yellow fever in Havana in 1879 as an undergraduate and medical clerk
of the U.S. Yellow Fever commission (by the bye the report of our
Chairman, DR. S. E. Chaille, published by the National Board of Health
is a perfect mine of information on all the phases of yellow fever and
is, in every sense, a masterful document. I saw the yellow fever for
the first time as a graduate of medecine in 1882, during the epidemics
which ravaged the Texan frontier on the Rio Grande in 1882that were especially
attacking Brownsville, Matamoros, and Mier and subsequently had occasion
to observe the milder epidemics in New Orleans of 1897-98. The paper
which I enclose is an introduction to the symposium on yellow fever

which was presented to the society in anticipation of the epidemic
which soon followed. When I look at this paper and others and the
discussions at that time, I feel like exclaiming “Tempora Mutantur,
etc”. Indeed how the times change!
